pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:0.4: The sub-chapter on containing living beings
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:1.2: At that time the monks from the group of six were reopening a legal issue that they knew had been legitimately settled, saying,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:1.3: “The legal procedure hasn’t been done; it’s been done badly; it should be done again; it’s not been settled; it’s been badly settled; it should be settled again.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:1.4: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:1.5: “How can the monks from the group of six reopen a legal issue that they know has been legitimately settled?” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:1.6: “Is it true, monks, that you are doing this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:1.9: Foolish men, how can you reopen a legal issue that you know has been legitimately settled?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:1.10: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:1.11: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:1.12: ‘If a monk reopens a legal issue that he knows has been legitimately settled, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:2.1.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a complete Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:2.1.6: he knows by himself or others have told him or the Sangha has told him.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:2.1.8: done according to the Teaching, according to the Monastic Law, according to the Teacher’s instruction—this is called “legitimately.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:2.1.10: there are four kinds of legal issues: legal issues arising from disputes, legal issues arising from accusations, legal issues arising from offenses, legal issues arising from proceedings.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:2.1.12: if he reopens it, saying, “The legal procedure hasn’t been done/it’s been done badly/it should be done again/it’s not been settled/it’s been badly settled/it should be settled again,” he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:2.2.1: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, and he perceives it as legitimate, and he reopens it, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:2.2.2: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, but he is unsure if it is, and he reopens it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:2.2.3: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, but he perceives it as illegitimate, and he reopens it, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:2.2.4: If it is an illegitimate legal procedure, but he perceives it as legitimate, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:2.2.5: If it is an illegitimate legal procedure, but he is unsure if it is, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:2.2.6: If it is an illegitimate legal procedure, and he perceives it as illegitimate, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:2.3.2: if he reopens it knowing that the legal procedure was done illegitimately, or by an incomplete Sangha, or to one who was not deserving a legal procedure;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:2.3.4: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63:2.3.5: The third rule, the training rule on reopening, is finished.
